Posts.Content: I've found this thread very encouraging.  Hereford Hospital now do the injection, not IV, for Herceptin and I start mine at the beginning of next month.  First of all though I have to have a heart scan and bone density scan, which I gather is normal procedure, and for the first injection I will have to stay around for a couple of hours to make sure there is no allergic reaction.   I don't know how the hospitals decide whether to do IV or injection but Hereford have changed over completely.
Posts.Title: Herceptin by injection

Posts.Content: Ooh, I know.  Life is hard enough at that point without snagging the drain!  My dog fell over my tubes on the stairs and pulled one right out!   Gill
Posts.Title: One Month Later - Mastectomy photos if anyone would like to see

Posts.Content: Mine was about 6 weeks.
Posts.Title: If you had mastectomy followed by chemo...

Posts.Content: A cross body bag with a long strap worked well for me.  At Hereford they have volunteers who make them out of pretty fabric and donate them.  The handle on mine went from the middle of each long side rather than the usual place and there must have been a reason for that!
Posts.Title: One Month Later - Mastectomy photos if anyone would like to see

Posts.Content: Hi, I was just like that before my mastectomy, but what was frightening me wasn't losing my breast, it was the radioactive isotope injection beforehand.  I had read horror stories on the web and got into a real stew about it.  In the end, of course, it was not nearly as bad as I expected.  Most things haven't been as bad as I expected, from having a broken leg set, to childbirth, to the MX so I tell myself now that I just have to go with the flow, and not get worked up beforehand.  I'm due to start FEC in two weeks.  We're all in this together, so be kind to yourself, and plan a little treat for when you feel up to it. Best of luck! xx
Posts.Title: Chemo tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi, I've now had 2 sessions of FEC.  I noticed just before I went for the 2nd one that the inside of my arm where I have the canula was sore as though I'd pulled a muscle.  When I mentioned it to the nurse who was administering the infusion she said it was the drugs that damaged the veins and that was what was causing the discomfort.  Is this quite normal and does it go away eventually?  I know I have to have all the infusions in my left arm because I had lymph nodes removed on the right along with the breast but it seems silly that I now have more movement in the side that was operated on than the apparently "healthy" side. Any comments welcome!
Posts.Title: FEC and sore veins

Posts.Content: I had a chemo planning consultation with a senior nurse, who told me to basically avoid the things that you avoid during pregnancy, i.e. soft or blue cheese, raw eggs, and also very crowded places and public swimming pools.  She didn't mention pate that I remember, but then that is cooked.  I think it's a matter of common sense and tailoring the advice to suit you and your life style.
Posts.Title: Yogurt

Posts.Content: Hi Kay, Had my 2nd FEC last Tuesday.  At least I knew what to expect but it doesn't make it any easier, I agree.  I'm telling myself that 1) if children and teenagers can go through it, so can I.  2) I couldn't forgive myself if I didn't do everything I could to prevent the cancer from returning and there was a 3) but chemo brain has struck!  I am so lucky that my partner, although we've only been living together for a year, is totally supportive and unpanicked.  (I lost my husband to bowel cancer 4 years ago).  Work are being brilliant, and saying that I mustn't think I have to try to go in, they will pay my salary anyway, and I haven't got small children to look after.  At a different time in my life this would have been much more difficult.  I feel totally supported by family and friends.   Sometimes however, it's the little reminders that upset me, like the pain in the arm, or the feeling of going outside bald to open up the hen house in the morning!   Stay strong, and look after yourself, Gill x
Posts.Title: FEC and sore veins

Posts.Content: Put in the search box " Advice re fasting during chemotherapy" and it should take you to a recent discussion.  Basically it suggests that you cut out carbs for 2 days before and 2 days after chemo.  I'm going to try it, starting on Sunday. I was going to cut and paste the link to it for you, but it won't let me paste! Gill
Posts.Title: diet

Posts.Content: And me please! Gill
Posts.Title: Advice re-fasting for chemotherapy.

Posts.Content: In Herefordshire they have to see you within 2 weeks.  Of course when I rang for an appointment they said they didn't have any appointments within the next 2 weeks and would ring me at short notice, which then happened while I was at work which wasn't ideal, but they did get me in in 10 days in the end.  It's a killer, waiting, isn't it?  I suppose the problem in your breast has been there a lot longer than you realise, so another 2 weeks shouldn't make a difference to the outcome.
Posts.Title: Do docs play down cancer until they get biopsy results or can they...

Posts.Content: I can only say that mine definitely worded his conversation following tests but before results to prepare me for cancer.  He actually said, I'm sure we are looking at surgery here.  I had to wait 5 days, and I was a bit weepy when I got the results but I wasn't shocked.   Waiting is the worst!  After that you are rushed from pillar to post with  appointments!
Posts.Title: Do docs play down cancer until they get biopsy results or can they...

Posts.Content: Not had mine done yet because the surgeon is waiting until I've finished chemo.  I am quite lopsided, but he judges that I am 2 sizes adtift and I don't think about it mostly.  However, it strikes me that it is very soon after your mx to be having the saline in your implant.  I thought they would wait a couple of months?  What do other people think?  Presumably if you are still sore you could choose to wait longer.
Posts.Title: tissue expander implants

Posts.Content: Not quite as bad as you, but I had my fourth FEC last Tuesday and it's taking me longer to get over it this time, even though for the first couple of days I convinced myself that it wasn't so bad as I had been following the diet where you cut out carbs just before and after chemo.  Some say the effects are cumulative and others disagree but I feel that they probably are, especially the exhaustion.
Posts.Title: Not tolerating chemo

Posts.Content: As regards nutrition, I am lucky enough to be near a Haven centre for breast cancer, and went to a talk from a nutritional therapist.  Her main point was that immediately after chemo you just eat whatever you can, then hopefully feel well enough for the next fortnight to build up your strength with good nutrition, but she was not very keen on amateur juicers!  They are apparently great if you use the right veg in them, but if you juice fruit in quantities there is enough sugar in it to be quite punishing to the liver and the liver has enough to do processing all the toxins from the chemo.  Very best of luck to all of you, and she is lucky to have a caring sister.  I have a very supportive family, and it makes all the difference.
Posts.Title: In shock, supporting my sister, how can I help?

Posts.Content: Sorry - remembered something else the nutritionist said - try and have some protein at every meal.  You do need red meat for iron when you are on chemo, but also eggs, cheese, nuts, seeds, beans etc.  It's all good stuff!  She emphasised that we probably all eat too much carbs.
Posts.Title: In shock, supporting my sister, how can I help?

Posts.Content: I was told to take 4 all at once in the morning for the following 3 days - so perhaps it's up to the oncologist, but I'm sure you start them tomorrow morning. Good luck Gill
Posts.Title: Dexamethasone following FEC

Posts.Content: Hi M65, I've just had my third FEC and find that after a couple of days I get horrendous diarrhoea.  I also have developed a pile and the diarrhoea makes it really sore, and when the blood count is low I definitely bleed more.  However black stools need checking out, unless you are on iron tablets.  The oncologist told me this time that I should have rung them about the stomach cramps and squits and he prescribed something for it. Best of luck, Gill
Posts.Title: FEC - sorry...question about piles and black stools!!

Posts.Content: And I thought it was only me! I told the surgeon he must have got the plumbing wrong!
Posts.Title: Weird sensations after mastectomy!

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy.  It sounds the same as I've had over the weekend.  Went to the GP this afternoon and apparently it is cellulitis caused by an insect bite and needs antibiotics so don't ignore it!  Best wishes Gill
Posts.Title: Insect bites

Posts.Content: Mine nearly all dropped out when the hair on my head went.  It hasn't caused me any discomfort but I'm sure that as the chemo kills off the mucous membrane cells it must change things internally.  Boots do a cream called Balance Activ which is supposed to restore the natural balance of flora etc which I have found good in the past, when I was sure I had "something" but not quite thrush.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Lost pubic hair. Very uncomfortable!

Posts.Content: I'm in the same boat as Karan, and the only herbal supplement that my oncologist approves of is sage tablets.  Everything else seems to contain phyto oestrogens which you have to avoid if your cancer was oestrogen positive.  I'm about to start acupuncture at The Haven in Hereford to see if that helps.
Posts.Title: Hot flushes/sweats

Posts.Content: In that case you should be able to take menopace tablets, which used to work brilliantly for me, but I can't take them now.   Good luck!
Posts.Title: Hot flushes/sweats
